summary: This document is an email chain from October 2, 2019, forwarded by Attorney General William Barr to the Office of the Attorney General (OAG) and then to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USANYS). It contains a forwarded message from an unidentified sender questioning the legal classification of a victim's case as child sex trafficking, citing specific details from the victim's testimony and depositions in the Jane Doe 102 vs. Jeffrey Epstein case. The email seeks clarification on the legal definition and asks for the matter to be directed to the appropriate channel.

persons.name: William Barr
persons.role: Attorney General of the United States
persons.context: Forwards an email regarding the Epstein case to the OAG, asking them to direct it to the appropriate person in the U.S. Attorney's office and to stop the sender from contacting him directly.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the sex trafficking case. The email references the victim's testimony about meeting him at his home and her subsequent activities.

persons.name: Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned alongside Epstein in the victim's testimony regarding meetings at Mar-a-Lago and involvement in arranging sexual activities.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Named as one of the individuals the victim was allegedly told to travel to have a sexual experience with, according to the forwarded email.

persons.name: Jack Scarola
persons.context: Referenced as one of the attorneys who conducted a telephone interview with the victim, which was later filed in 2011.

persons.name: Brad Edward
persons.context: Referenced as one of the attorneys who conducted a telephone interview with the victim, which was later filed in 2011.

persons.name: Ms. Sarnoff
persons.context: The original sender of the email questioning the trafficking classification, whom Barr references as needing a point of contact to stop her from 'lobbing this stuff' to him.

connections.description: Described in the victim's testimony as acting together in recruiting her and arranging sexual activities.
Prince Andrew is described as an 'alleged Epstein friend' whom the victim was told to travel to meet for sex.
Ms. Sarnoff is corresponding with the Attorney General about the legal classification of the Epstein case, indicating she is an external party commenting on it.
Both are attorneys referenced as having conducted a joint telephone interview with the victim.

events.title: Filing of Jane Doe 102 vs. Jeffrey Epstein
events.description: The initial complaint in the civil case Jane Doe 102 vs. Jeffrey Epstein was filed in the Southern District of Florida.

events.title: Filing of victim's telephone interview
events.description: A telephone interview with the victim conducted by attorneys Jack Scarola and Brad Edward was filed as part of the legal record.

events.title: Email correspondence regarding trafficking definition
events.description: An email chain is initiated questioning the legal basis for classifying the victim's case as child sex trafficking, which is forwarded up to Attorney General William Barr.

keyFacts: A victim (Jane Doe 102) testified she began having sex with Epstein, Maxwell, and others at age 15, quitting her job as a bathroom attendant at Mar-a-Lago to do so for more money.

The victim's testimony, as cited, describes voluntary travel and agreements to sexual activities without claims of force, fraud, or coercion, leading to questions about the legal definition of trafficking.
The victim allegedly traveled to London and elsewhere to have sexual experiences with Prince Andrew and other friends of Epstein, doing so voluntarily according to the email.
Attorney General William Barr personally forwarded an email questioning the trafficking charges to the OAG, asking them to handle it and stop the sender from contacting him directly.
The email seeks a clarification of the legal definition of child sex trafficking for prosecutors, law enforcement, and field workers.
